titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: William Healey Dall was a noted natural historian, paleontologist, and malacologist. In 1865 he was appointed as a member of the Scientific Corps to the Western Union Telegraph Expedition to Alaska and the Yukon. From 1871-1884, Dall worked for the United States Coast Survey. In 1884 he was appointed as Paleontologist with the United States Geological Survey, a position he held until 1925. Dall's greatest scientific contributions were in the field of malacology. Working on both fossil (Tertiary) and living mollusks, he described over 5300 species. In 1893, the Wagner Free Institute of Science elected Dall Honorary Professor of Invertebrate Paleontology. In recognition of his contributions to science the Trustees of the Institute awarded Dall a medal on June 7, 1899.

scopecontent.p: The William Healey Dall collection consists of a medal, scientific instruments, and a photograph. The medal of the Wagner Free Institute of Science was awarded to Dall in 1899 for his "investigations and writings in paleontology." It is the only medal ever awarded by the Institute. The collection of scientific instruments belonging to Dall includes, a dissecting kit Dall used on his first expedition to Alaska in 1865, a pocket thermometer, a pocket compass, a pocket barometer/altimeter, and a fire-lighter. The card photograph of Dall is from "Geo. Prince, Artistic Portraits, Penn Ave. & 11th St., Washington, D.C." that was probably taken when he was in his thirties.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Provenance: All items in collection donated by Whitney and Barbara Dall.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
